element.name: 3.8 Quality Criteria for Work Products and Requirements

stereotype.name: 3.8 Quality Criteria for Work Products and Requirements

stereotype.text: <See Handbook for the CPRE Foundation Level according to the IREB Standard v.1.10 / 3.8 Quality Criteria for Work Products and Requirements>

There is no differentiation between a stakeholder need and a system requirement. A stakeholder need describes the expectations of the stakeholder towards the system without knowing its details. A systems requirement describes expected behaviours/properties of elements within the system.
A requirement shall describe true stakeholder needs.

There is no objective "true" evaluation for a requirement or need. A truth must be accepted by all parties. Therefore a requirement/need must be reviewed and accepted by all parties in order to be "true".
A requirement shall describe agreed stakeholder needs.
A requirement should contribute to the achievement of at least one stakeholder goal or need.
A requirement should be interpretable the same way by everybody involved.
A requirement should miss no parts that are necessary for understanding.
A requirement shall be fully understandable by the target audience.

A requirement shall be indisputably checkable for its fulfillment by an implemented system, so that stakeholders or customers can decide whether or not a requirement is fulfilled by the implemented system.
A requirement should not contradict another requirement.
A requirement should be documented only once.
A requirement should not overlap with another requirement.
A requirements specification should contain all relevant requirements (functionalrequirements, quality requirements, and constraints) that are known at this point in time.
A requirements specification should contain all relevant requirements (functionalrequirements, quality requirements, and constraints) that are that are related to this specification.
A requirements specification should be set up in such a way that it can be modified without degrading its quality.
A requirement should be traceable back to their origins.
A requirement should be traceable forward to their implementation (in design, code, and test).
A requirement should be traceable to other requirements they depend on.
If there are mandatory structuring or formatting instructions, a requirement should conform to them.

element.name: 7.2.4.1 Characteristics of Requirements and Designs Quality

stereotype.name: 7.2.4.1 Characteristics of Requirements and Designs Quality

stereotype.text: <See Handbook for the CPRE Foundation Level according to the IREB Standard v.1.10 / 3.8 Quality Criteria for Work Products and Requirements>
A requirement should be self-contained.
A requirement should be capable of being understood independently of other requirements or designs.
A requirement should be complete enough to guide further work.
The level of completeness required shall differ based on perspective or methodology, as well as the point in the life cycle where the requirement is being examined or represented.
A requirement should be at the appropriate level of detail for work to continue.
A requirement should be aligned with the identified needs of the stakeholders.
A requirement should not conflict with other requirements.
A requirement should contains no extraneous content.
A requirement should contains no unnecessary content.
A requirement should be reasonably feasible and possible within the agreed-upon risk, schedule, and budget.
A requirement should be considered feasible enough to investigate further through experiments or prototypes.
A requirement should be clearly stated in such a way to make it clear whether a solution does or does not meet the associated need.
A requirement should be able to verify that the requirement or design has been fulfilled.
Acceptable levels of verifying fulfillment depend on the level of abstraction of the requirement or design.
A requirement should be ranked, grouped, or negotiated in terms of importance and value against all other requirements.
A requirement should be represented using common terminology of the audience.
I want to achieve the objectives within the given contraints in order to ensure the organizations success.
I want to complete the mission within the scope ranges in order to stay within the given contraints.
I want to define the scope of the mission in order to stay within the scope ranges.
I want to complete the mission within the quality ranges in order to stay within the given contraints.
I want to complete the mission within the available resources in order to stay within the given contraints.
I want to estimate the resources needed for development in order to predict if the mission is able to stay within the available resources.
I want to quantify the system requirements, in order to be able to estimate the resources needed for their implementation.
I want to complete the mission within the given timeline in order to stay within the given contraints.
I want to estimate the time needed for development in order to predict if the mission is able stay within the given timeline.
I want to quantify the system requirements, in order to be able to estimate the time needed for their implementation.
I want to complete the mission within the benefit ranges in order to stay within the given contraints.
I want to complete the mission within the acceptable risks in order to stay within the given contraints.
A stakeholder need shall be reviewed by the stakeholder and the supplier in order to receive feedback or acceptance.
A stakeholder need shall be reviewed by the stakeholder and the supplier in order to receive feedback or acceptance.
A stakeholder need should not make
<See Automotive Spice 3.1 / Process Reference Model / SUP.8 Configuration Management / Process purpose>
The configuration management process shall establish the integrity of all work products of a process or project.
The configuration management process shall maintain the integrity of all work products of a process or project.
The configuration management process shall make all work products of a process or project available to affected parties.
<See Automotive Spice 3.1 / Process Reference Model / SUP.8 Configuration Management / Process outcome 1>
The configuration management process shall develop a strategy for configuration management.
<See Automotive Spice 3.1 / Process Reference Model / SUP.8 Configuration Management / Process outcome 2>
The configuration management process shall identify all configuration items generated by a process or project according to the configuration management strategy.
The configuration management process shall define all configuration items generated by a process or project according to the configuration management strategy.
The configuration management process shall baseline all configuration items generated by a process or project according to the configuration management strategy.
<See Automotive Spice 3.1 / Process Reference Model / SUP.8 Configuration Management / Process outcome 3>
The configuration management process shall control modifications of the configuration items.
The configuration management process shall control releases of the configuration items.
<See Automotive Spice 3.1 / Process Reference Model / SUP.8 Configuration Management / Process outcome 4>
The configuration management process shall make modifications available to affected parties.
The configuration management process shall make releases available to affected parties.
<See Automotive Spice 3.1 / Process Reference Model / SUP.8 Configuration Management / Process outcome 5>
The configuration management process shall record the status of configuration items.
The configuration management process shall record the status of modification.
The configuration management process shall report the status of configuration items.
The configuration management process shall report the status of modification.
<See Automotive Spice 3.1 / Process Reference Model / SUP.8 Configuration Management / Process outcome 6>
The configuration management process shall ensure the completeness of the baselines.
The configuration management process shall ensure the consistency of the baselines.
<See Automotive Spice 3.1 / Process Reference Model / SUP.8 Configuration Management / Process outcome 7>
The configuration management process shall control the storage of the configuration items.
<See Automotive Spice 3.1 / Process Reference Model / SUP.8 Configuration Management / Base practice 1>
The configuration management process shall develop a configuration management strategy.
The configuration management strategy shall include responsibilities.
The configuration management strategy shall include tools.
The configuration management strategy shall include repositories.
The configuration management strategy shall include criteria for configuration items.
The configuration management strategy shall include naming conventions.
The configuration management strategy shall include access rights.
The configuration management strategy shall include criteria for baselines;
The configuration management strategy shall include a merge strategy.
The configuration management strategy shall include a branch strategy.
The configuration management strategy shall include the revision history approach for configuration items.
The configuration management strategy should typically supports the handling of product/software variants which may be caused by different sets of application parameters or by other causes.
The branch management strategy should specify in which cases branching is permissible.
The branch management strategy should specify whether authorization is required.
The branch management strategy should specify how branches are merged.
The branch management strategy should specify which activities are required to verify that all changes have been consistently integrated without damage to other changes or to the original software.
<See Automotive Spice 3.1 / Process Reference Model / SUP.8 Configuration Management / Base practice 2>
The configuration management process shall identify configuration items.
The configuration management process shall identify configuration items according to the configuration management strategy.
The configuration management process shall document configuration items according to the configuration management strategy.

The configuration management process should apply configuration control for the products that are delivered to the customer, designated internal work products, acquired products, tools and other configuration items that are used in creating and describing these work products.
<See Automotive Spice 3.1 / Process Reference Model / SUP.8 Configuration Management / Base practice 3>
The configuration management process shall establish a configuration management system.
The configuration management process shall establish a configuration management system according to the configuration management strategy.
<See Automotive Spice 3.1 / Process Reference Model / SUP.8 Configuration Management / Base practice 4>
The configuration management process shall establish branch management according to the configuration management strategy for parallel developments that use the same base.
<See Automotive Spice 3.1 / Process Reference Model / SUP.8 Configuration Management / Base practice 5>
The configuration management process shall control modifications.
The configuration management process shall control releases.
The configuration management process shall establish mechanisms for the control of the configurations items according to the configuration management strategy.
I want to control modifications using these mechanisms.
I want to control releases using these mechanisms.
<See Automotive Spice 3.1 / Process Reference Model / SUP.8 Configuration Management / Base practice 6>
The configuration management process shall establish baselines for internal purposes according to the configuration management strategy.
The configuration management process shall establish baselines for external delivery according to the configuration management strategy.
The configuration management process shall refer to the product release process SPL.2 for baseline issues.
<See Automotive Spice 3.1 / Process Reference Model / SUP.8 Configuration Management / Base practice 7>
The configuration management process shall report configuration status.
The configuration management process shall record status of configuration items to support project management and other relevant processes.
The configuration management process shall report status of configuration items to support project management and other relevant processes.
<See Automotive Spice 3.1 / Process Reference Model / SUP.8 Configuration Management / Base practice 8>
The configuration management process shall verify the information about configured items.
The configuration management process shall verify that the information about configured items is complete.
The configuration management process shall verify that the information about configured items' baselines is complete.
The configuration management process shall ensure the consistency of baselines.
The configuration management process should implement this as baseline audits.
The configuration management process should implement this as configuration management audits.
<See Automotive Spice 3.1 / Process Reference Model / SUP.8 Configuration Management / Base practice 9>
The configuration management process shall manage the storage of configuration items.
The configuration management process shall manage the storage of baselines.

The configuration management process shall ensure the integrity of configuration items through appropriate scheduling and resourcing of storage, archiving (long term storage) and backup of the used CM systems.equirements.

The configuration management process shall ensure the integrity of baselines through appropriate scheduling and resourcing of storage, archiving (long term storage) and backup of the used CM systems.equirements.

The configuration management process shall ensure the availability of configuration items through appropriate scheduling and resourcing of storage, archiving (long term storage) and backup of the used CM systems.equirements.

The configuration management process shall ensure the availability of baselines through appropriate scheduling and resourcing of storage, archiving (long term storage) and backup of the used CM systems.equirements.
The configuration management process shall extend storage beyond guaranteed lifetime of available storage media.
The configuration management process shall extend archiving beyond guaranteed lifetime of available storage media.
The configuration management process shall include relevant, affected configuration items as referenced in note 2 and note 3.
The configuration management process shall ensure availability as specified by contract requirements.
A requirement should describe only a single property or function of a single system element.

Alternatives: - Singular is too ambiguous, has multiple interpretations - Self-contained is about no outside references - Independent same as self-contained - Decomposed would be a property of a requirements specification

The requirement should be independent meaning it is describe without reference to other requirements, in order to prevent inconsistencies between requirements and enhance understanding of the requirement.
The requirement shall be detailed enough, in order to enable effective development activities.
The requirement shall be consistent with all other requirements, to avoid competing development activities and/or system disruption.
The requirement shall be specific to only the system, to avoid unfeasible development efforts.
The requirement shall be feasible with the available resources and constraints, to ensure sustainable and effective development.
The requirement should be prioritized according to their importance, to support the expected order of releases and limit dependency risks.
The requirement shall be unambiguous, to prevent differing interpretations between stakeholder and development team.
The requirement should be comprehensible, to support a common understanding of the requirement between stakeholder and development team.
The requirement shall be testable, to support validation and verification activities.
The requirement should be unique, to avoid duplicate planning of development efforts and inconsistencies between requirements.
The requirement shall be identifiable, to support traceability and improve clear communication.
The requirement should be traceable to its origin, to support change management and stakeholder acceptance.
The requirement should be mapped to elements in the system, to support planning of development and effective use of resources.
The requirement may be conforming with defined formats to support understanding between stakeholder and development team.
The requirement shall be derived from stakeholder input, to avoid extraneous development efforts.
The requirement should be analyzed by the development team, to understand its impact on the system and development.
The requirement should be reviewed by the stakeholder and the development team, to ensure informed agreement.
The requirement shall be agreed upon by the stakeholder and the development team, to ensure accountability and support the establishment of baselines.
The requirement should be tangible
The requirement may use its own data type.
A system element shall have a status within the element lifecycle in order to ??? account for maturity???
The element lifecycle shall contain an Open status, in order to indicate that no work has been done yet.
The element lifecycle may contain a Draft status, in order to indicate the system element is not
